intro: Horkelia fusca var. pseudocapitata, commonly known as the Sierra foothill gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Polemoniaceae family and is characterized by its showy, blue to purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats, such as slopes and gravelly soils, and is often found in California and parts of Nevada. It has hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves, and its flowers are arranged in clusters at the ends of the stems. This species is adapted to arid environments and plays a role in supporting local pollinators.
